displayed_text: Family Member: Xofigo. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: Do you think he’s qualified to go away on a vacation for a couple of weeks? Doctor: Uh hum, yeah – when are you going? Healthcare Professional: When are you going on vacation? Doctor: Yeah, I get to go. Family Member: February fifth till – Doctor: Oh yeah, because even if you start in January, it’s monthly, so. Family Member: So February fifth till like the twenty, till like the twenty-second or something. Doctor: Oh that’s fine. That’s fine. Family Member: So we have to schedule that around then. Doctor: Oh yeah, he’ll, trust me, we will hunt you down. He will hunt you down because every time you’re about to get a dose, it’s fifteen thousand dollars a dose.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: because weirdly enough it’s IV so it’s not a pill like what you’ve been on with all of your prior treatments. Patient: Right. Okay. Doctor: Anything else we’re missing? The other thing that’s hard about Xofigo though is that sometimes it doesn’t make the PSA go down. In fact, two-thirds of the people the PSA rises up and you’re like is this stuff in me, hello, are these guys pocketing it or what’s going on and it’s just something that happens bone wise that sometimes you just see almost the worsening of the PSA and yours is already going up so I bring that up so it won’t be like oh, my god, she’s ah, doesn’t she not know it’s higher. Patient: The conference we went to I learned about that. Doctor: Yes, you did. Patient: So that, that was well worth being there just for that. Doctor: Oh, I’m so glad. Patient: So I’m well aware of that. Doctor: Awesome. Patient: I told my kids that. I said, oh man, that’s, yeah, so I understand that. Doctor: Yeah, so you know it’s something we consider but just so you know we don’t combine the two, right.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.1 time: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::1 time

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.disagree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::disagree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.neutral: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::neutral

All in all, you trust doctors completely.agree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::agree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::agree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.12 years or completed high school: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::12 years or completed high school

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.Yes, Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::Yes, Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Some other race: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Some other race

displayed_text: Patient: Right. Doctor: and whatever’s on sale you just sort of do that and you get your own little recipe thing going. Patient: Right. Doctor: It’s harder when it’s sort of the ad hoc like well, I’m gonna take one here and take one here for your bowels to know so the more regular you are your bowels will appreciate that too. Patient: Okay. I understand. Yeah, I was doing that before. I was holding off. I, you know… Doctor: Yeah No holding. Patient: Okay. Alright. Doctor: So, this is a prescription for Norco so theres, you know, it’s five slash three-twenty-five Patient: Okay. Doctor: so I think we provided one hundred twenty Patient: Right. Doctor: so we don’t want you to run out. Obviously, if you take all one hundred twenty at one time you’re in trouble so don’t do that. Patient: I would say, yeah I’m not gonna do that.

Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: …and we’re gonna go over just the research part of it, so this is literally bio-specimen acquiring study which means when after we biopsy we’re gonna take several passes more to get extra stuff and that’s the end. And we won’t do it – Patient: Take the whole - Doctor: Take the whole thing out! (laughs) Patient: No, take the whole damn thing out. Patient: Take it all! Doctor: I know. The needle is yeh big and this thing is still yeh big so uh we would have to do a lot of passes. Patient: da Vinci procedure, da Vinci procedure. Doctor: Look at you. Get you on the table just like that. (laughs) Patient: da Vinci procedure (makes whistle noise) Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Snip, snip, snip, bzzz. (makes various noises) Doctor: See that. You’re

Patient: …and then we’re gonna do some evaluations, we’re gonna make some decisions and we’ll… Doctor: Okay. Patient: …we’ll formalize a plan and we’ll go from there. Doctor: Yes. And then you go on vacation, when you come back we’ll have more data. Patient: Sure. Doctor: And then we have multitude of options including standard pills… Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: …standard chemo, and/or clinical studies of which there are several. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Good. Doctor: So I’m gonna have M____ come in… Patient: Mhmm.

Patient: Yeah. Chloraseptic. Doctor: That might help. Or when you’re at the drugstore picking up your ibuprofen, there’s liquid saliva. Okay? So like you have the liquid tears. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: There’s artificial saliva. So that if this side of your mouth isn’t making the saliva, you can put some of that in, and just moisten it up. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Because again, you are sort of, your tongue’s sort of moving over, but your brain looks good. Doctor: Okay? Patient: All right. Doctor: But if it gets worse, it don’t make sense, I’d go back to the ER because I don’t know, because that’s what I would say, and it looks like your tongue’s a little bit more trouble getting over, huh, than the last time. Patient: Okay. I mean, these sometime it’s off and on. Sometimes I can you know- Doctor: Well, when you get tired it can do it. Patient: Yeah. So.

Patient: Yeah. Patient: Huh. Yeah bring in, lets take a look at it… Doctor: Yeah you’ll probably need the copy of the labs anyway. Patient: Yeah but that’s what… Doctor: You’ll have to take it to B____ too. Patient: Huh? Doctor: I want you to take the blood work, the tests that I give you to B____ also. Patient: Okay. Oh, okay. Doctor: That way they have a copy. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Right. Patient: Okay, okay. Yeah because that’s what we did last…

Patient: Okay. Doctor: We may have at the start of this study. Uh, uh, and it can change with therapy. So, you would have to repeat it again. Um, and you’ve had Enzalutamide, so I think you’d be good to go on that one. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Uh, that you actually would stay on the Enzalutamide and if you’re AR-V7 positive, well then we have, uh, some of the new list of new therapies that are being used in other tumor types. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And, then, we’re looking to see what they’re likelihood of benefiting men with prostate cancer are. Patient: Okay. Doctor: We have done a handful of men before, and the handful of men seemed to have their PSA drop for awhile. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: But, it’s not the mega excitement in prostate cancer, uh, that we see with the other tumors that you hear on the news with Jimmy Carter and all of those kinds of – Patient: Right, right. Doctor: Um, it can possibly benefit people for awhile.

Patient: Who knows. Doctor: Since he’s been on Xtandi. Family Member: She buries her head. Doctor: That’s it I’m leaving. Family Member: Okay good. And she's going to explain about the trial? Doctor: And the schedule just to make sure it's something that you're even going to do. Family Member: Dr. H___ can I give you a hug? Doctor: Yay! Family Member: I need someone like you in my life. Doctor: Aw thank you. You’re so great. Family Member: I appreciate it. Doctor: Don't go anywhere.

Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: In about thirty to forty percent of patients it causes remissions. In other words it causes cancer either to shrink um partially or completely in addition to the PSA level to drop either partially or completely. Patient: I don’t understand how. Could you give me the basic outline as to how that is happening? Let’s say you have the person who is overweight; you give him more food. That doesn’t – Doctor: Yeah, as I said, as you pointed out, it seems like a paradox and it seems counterintuitive. Patient: Right, right. Doctor: And the reason is it has to do with the fact that um when the prostate cancer cell, the cancer cell has been in an environment where the testosterone has been deprived for so long, and then all of a sudden you give that cell back a super-high dose of testosterone, it shocks the system and it causes that cell to die. And the exact reason for that we’ve begun to tease it out and understand it better. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: It turns out that the genetic material of the cancer cell, which is called the DNA. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: - in order for that cancer cell to be able to replicate itself, to cause you know two cells from one and then four cells, eight cells, it needs to be able to replicate its DNA and then replicate itself after that. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: And it turns out when you give high doses of testosterone in the setting where that cell has previously been in a low testosterone environment - Patient: Okay.

Patient: Right. Doctor: Sort of like this is different than the Elida which is always in your system. You take it every day. The chemo is in your system, but it peaks, you know, kind of seven to 10 days. You're like, “yeah, I don’t feel so great. I'm not gonna run the marathon.” But then you kind of come down and you're like, “oh, okay, great. It's three weeks later, and I feel great right in time for me to give you the next treatment. Doctor: It’s the roller coaster that I'm not sure you're really looking forward to where you rise up again. But we're hoping that it's not as severe. You know, part of the goal for development of any new medicine is that you hope it's better than the current one. Patient: Okay. Family Member 1: What about sleeping? He’s having trouble sleeping right now? Doctor: No, do you think it has something to do with the steroids, Dexamethasone that you're taking? Because that kind of wakes people up. Patient: No. Ever since I've been on Erlida I've had trouble sleeping. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Yeah. It just takes me forever to- Doctor: Yeah. Patient: -get to sleep. Doctor: When was the last time you took that medication? Patient: The Erlida?

Patient: I can’t talk. Like somebody’s stoppin’ and be talkin’ to me. But, let’s go walk up so ‘cuz I can’t stand up that long. Doctor: I see. Patient: And, also, I’ll be out of breath and then my legs Doctor: Yeah, Okay. Patient: get weak. I can, um, I’m all for the standing and talk, bro, that we are gonna talk, let’s sit down. Doctor: So, what do you want to do? Do you want to take a break from the chemotherapy? Patient: Um, it’s up to you, dear. What’s your take, doctor? I think it, it’s Doctor: It’s been working very well against your cancer… Patient: Okay. And they had my blood tests came back? Doctor: Your PSA’s not back from today, but last time, it was continuing to go down. Patient: What was it? What was it? Doctor: Your PSA was one seventy-three..

Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: So if the majority of your Gleason pattern is higher than tree, and the small minority is higher than four, since you have more of the four and less then the three to more Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: If you are a lot more than then they’re gonna Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: So you have an intermediate risk, but potentially . Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Which actually will be sort of . So if you feel comfortable continuing with the next step, the next step will be for me to get a Patient: Okay. Yeah I’m interested uh huh so if the next step is I’ll read this and I’ll talk to my wife and my children and I’ve basically tell them this is the route that I wanted to go as far as radiation. I mean you’ve given me enough information with the random selection- Doctor: Correct. Patient: so I understand. My biggest concern is around the randmon selection is how long I’ll remain in that before actually having… Doctor: Right, now one thing to say about that and this is true of every clinical trial, you have the option to if you don’t want to.

Patient: doctor Doctor: Hey, how are ya? I’m going to just go through a couple of questions with you. Family Member: Ok. Doctor: Catch things up. Patient: Alright. Doctor: No new allergies? Patient: No. Doctor: Uh, the medicines that you take. You’re on – I thought you’re taking your, uh, apixaban or Eliquis? Five milligrams? Patient: Right. Doctor: You take that once a day, twice a day? Patient: Twice a day uh. Once in the morning and once at night. (Pause) Doctor: And then bupropion or Wellbutrin a hundred and fifty milligrams a day? Or twice a day? Patient: Twice, uh, I think they are seventy milligrams twice a day.

Family Member: Do you have the results of today’s draw, blood draw? Doctor: I was told that he did not have blood drawn. Did he have it? Family Member: Yeah. Oh, yeah. Doctor: Yeah. No. I don’t, then. I’ll, uh, check. I’ll bring you the results. I don’t think I have a PSA back. Family Member: Oh. Right. Doctor: But, uh- Patient: So what, what involves, getting a shot every month or so? Doctor: Every six weeks, if you go on it. Patient: Every six weeks? Doctor: Yes. Patient: Hum. Well, what happens if I wanted to go to England and get it or Germany? Doctor: You’re a free man. You can go any time.
